Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Adaptation to Highly Unpredictable Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Venicia Slotten a doctoral dissertation student will undertake research to study long term diet and resource procurement strategies in a region of volcanic activity. This region experiences powerful volcanic activity every few centuries, which dramatically impacts the landscape and alters the ecosystems that people used to obtain their basic resources for food, tools, and medicine. Archaeological investigations are well suited for this study because they allow for a long-term view of past lives and will allow the project to investigate particular land management and settlement strategies that aided peoples to continue living in such a dynamic landscape over a long time through at least three major volcanic eruptions. This investigation will explore how people coped with natural disasters by demonstrating the plant-human interactions that were vital in long-term survival and could have helped the ancient inhabitants maintain resilience within their environmental setting, thus illustrating fruitful paths for future disasters.

Slotten and her research team will excavate domestic contexts of a volcanically preserved village site. Examining household contexts will allow the investigators to focus on everyday practices in the past and to gain a better understanding of daily life styles. The research will be conducted on a lake shoreline to uncover household structures that are being actively washed away by the seasonally fluctuating lake levels. Remaining archaeological materials will be recovered before the site is completely destroyed. Since ecosystem management is one of the main domains of adaptive strategies that societies have employed throughout history in order to deal with their environment, this project will focus on the recovery of preserved plant material in order to reconstruct past ecological management and knowledge. At the core of the research design is a systematic collection of botanical data, including macrobotanical remains (seeds and wood charcoal) as well as microbotanical remains (pollen, phytoliths, and starch). Botanical remains are a critical component towards understanding the basic lives of traditional people, as their main material engagement within the landscape was with plants. The team will generate environmental models to aid in the interpretation of past migrations and resettlement as a result of volcanic activity and explore the potential for multi-community engagements and relationships in the past.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Venicia Slotten has completed research for her dissertation “Forests and Foods of Ancient Arenal: Archaeological and Paleoethnobotanical Investigations of Resilience in a Volcanically Active Landscape” supported by the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant. During her funding period, she spent over three months in Tronadora, Guanacaste, Costa Rica to conduct archaeological excavations at G-164 Sitio Bolivar, which was inhabited circa 500 CE (the Late Arenal time period). She was specifically focused on the horizontal excavation and paleoethnobotanical recovery of preserved food remains of a domestic structure within this ancient village site.

The data that Slotten collected from the archaeological excavations is the foundation for an argument she is constructing about the past foodways and resilient practices of ancient Central Americans. Sitio Bolivar yielded a robust plant assemblage through the collection of 137 flotation samples and resulted in the recovery of over 3,000 wood charcoal fragments, 4,700 seeds and fruits, as well as over 60 geophyte fragments. After two years of analysis of the plant remains, over 100 different botanical genera were identified at G164 Sitio Bolivar. Over 60 of these botanical genera produce edible plant parts (fruits, seeds, leaves, roots) such as maize, beans, squash, cacao, achiote, avocado, cashew, guava, guanabana, fig, coyol, quinoa, breadnut, passion fruit, purslane, mamey, and tobacco. This is the largest paleoethnobotanical data set of macrobotanical remains thus far recovered and identified in the country of Costa Rica and in Lower Central America overall.

The dissertation project has provided training in the collection of botanical remains to numerous students from the University of Costa Rica as well as training in the archaeological identification of seeds and wood charcoal to numerous undergraduate research apprenticeships students at the University of California Berkeley. Several of these students have used their experience with this project in their successful applications to graduate schools, in which they will use this knowledge of scanning electron microscopy and wood identification in their own future research projects. The flotation machine constructed for the collection of these botanical remains was donated to the Anthropology department at the University of Costa Rica in order to encourage further botanical investigations on other archaeological projects.

To be completed in August of 2024, the dissertation is an important contribution to the study of the past because it exemplifies the incredibly diverse plant assemblage that composed past peoples’ diets in this ecologically hazardous setting over several millennia using a mixture of both agricultural and agroforestry strategies of food procurement. This diet formed a lifestyle in which their food practices were resilient to their ever changing landscape because they could rely on resources that would survive volcanic eruptions and be available even if they were temporarily displaced to nearby regions.
